title: Quiz 5: January 2011 Licensure Exam (Paper Two)
description: Comprehensive review of the January 2011 Paper Two Licensure Examination, focusing on high-risk obstetrics, embryology, and labour management.

questions.question: Which of the following is a fetal cause of early pregnancy loss?

options.text: Structural abnormalities of the genital tract
Infections such as rubella, listeria and Chlamydia

questions.explanation: Chromosomal abnormalities (e.g., trisomies) are the single most common cause of spontaneous abortion in the first trimester.
questions.hint: It relates to the genetics of the embryo.

questions.question: The outcome of labor is dependent on the '3 Ps'. Which of the following is NOT one of the primary determinants?

options.text: The degree of moulding of the fetal head

questions.explanation: Labor outcome depends on Powers (contractions), Passage (pelvis/joints), and Passenger (fetal moulding). General maternal size is less critical than pelvic capacity.
questions.hint: Height and weight matter less than the pelvis shape.

questions.question: When monitoring fetal well-being using a fetal kick chart, a client should notify the midwife if she counts:
questions.explanation: Standard protocols (like the Cardiff count) suggest 10 movements should be felt within a specific period (often 2-12 hours). Less than 10 movements over a prolonged period (3 hours) indicates reduced activity.
questions.hint: Reduced movement is a warning sign.

questions.question: During discharge, what important advice regarding nutrition should be given to a breastfeeding mother?

options.text: Routinely avoid onions, cabbage and chocolate
Keep calcium intake the same as during pregnancy
Return to pre-pregnancy intake for proteins but not calories

questions.explanation: Lactation is energy-intensive, requiring approximately 500 kcal/day above pre-pregnancy needs (more than the ~300 kcal extra needed during pregnancy).
questions.hint: Making milk burns a lot of energy.

questions.question: In which part of the uterus does a contraction begin?
questions.explanation: The physiological pacemakers of the uterus are located at the cornua (near the tubal ostia), initiating the wave of contraction.
questions.hint: Where the tubes enter.

questions.question: FSH and LH are secreted by which gland?
questions.explanation: The Anterior Pituitary secretes gonadotropins (FSH and LH).
questions.hint: The master gland's front section.

questions.question: Uterine contractions are controlled by:
questions.explanation: The uterus is innervated by the Autonomic Nervous System (ANS), although hormonal control is the primary driver of labor.
questions.hint: It controls involuntary bodily functions.

questions.question: What is the normal volume of amniotic fluid after 20 weeks gestation?
questions.explanation: Amniotic fluid volume peaks at 800-1000ml in the third trimester. 500-1000ml is the standard normal range.
questions.hint: Roughly up to a liter.

questions.question: The ectoderm differentiates to form the:
questions.explanation: The Ectoderm forms the nervous system (CNS/PNS) and skin. Mesoderm forms CV/Connective tissue. Endoderm forms Respiratory/Digestive tracts.
questions.hint: Outer layer = Skin and Nerves.

questions.question: Which hormone maintains the endometrium and stimulates breast alveoli development during pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Progesterone is the 'pro-gestation' hormone that maintains the decidua and prepares breasts for lactation.
questions.hint: The hormone of pregnancy.

questions.question: The anteroposterior diameter of the pelvic outlet measures approximately:
questions.explanation: While anatomically smaller, the mobility of the coccyx during labor allows the AP diameter of the outlet to expand to ~13 cm.
questions.hint: The coccyx moves back to make room.

questions.question: How does the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) change during pregnancy?
questions.explanation: GFR increases by ~50% in pregnancy due to increased renal blood flow.
questions.hint: The kidneys work much harder.

questions.question: Signs of cardiac decompensation in a pregnant woman are most likely to appear at:
questions.explanation: The peak hemodynamic burden (max cardiac output and blood volume) occurs at 28-32 weeks.
questions.hint: The peak of blood volume expansion.

questions.question: Which mechanism of labor allows the fetal head to fit the widest anteroposterior diameter of the pelvic outlet?
questions.explanation: Internal rotation aligns the long axis of the fetal head with the long axis (AP diameter) of the pelvic outlet.
questions.hint: Turning from sideways to face the back.

questions.question: Closure of the newborn's foramen ovale occurs when:

options.text: Blood flows from pulmonary artery to aorta
Left atrial pressure exceeds right atrial pressure

questions.explanation: Functional closure occurs due to pressure changes: decreased right atrial pressure (lungs open) and increased left atrial pressure (systemic resistance).
questions.hint: Pressure flip.

questions.question: Why is the newborn with post-maturity syndrome at high risk for cold stress?
questions.explanation: Post-term infants lose subcutaneous fat due to placental insufficiency, reducing insulation against cold.
questions.hint: They look 'wasted' and have less insulation.

questions.question: The presence of meconium in the newborn's lungs:

options.text: Traps inspired air in the alveoli
Prevents air from entering the airway

questions.explanation: Meconium causes a ball-valve effect: air enters but cannot exit, leading to air trapping and hyperinflation.
questions.hint: Ball-valve effect.

questions.question: Which symptom is characteristic of superficial thrombophlebitis?

options.text: Local redness and tenderness in a portion of the vein
Edema of the ankle and lower leg
Pain in the affected leg and foot

questions.explanation: Superficial thrombophlebitis presents as a palpable, tender, red cord. Edema and Homan's sign are for DVT.
questions.hint: You can see and feel the red line.

questions.question: Which statements are TRUE regarding obstetric maneuvers?

options.text: Wood's Maneuver uses anterior pressure on the fetal shoulder
Zavanelli Maneuver involves pushing the fetal head back into the birth canal

questions.explanation: Wood's Screw maneuver applies pressure to the posterior aspect of the shoulder to rotate. Zavanelli is cephalic replacement for C-section.
questions.hint: One is a rotation, the other is a desperate return.

questions.question: Which of the following are DIRECT causes of Placenta Abruption? (Select 2)
questions.explanation: Direct mechanical causes include trauma, short cord (traction), and sudden decompression (loss of volume).
questions.hint: Mechanical forces.

questions.question: Arrange the steps of Fertilization in the correct chronological order:
questions.explanation: Sperm prepares (Capacitation), releases enzymes (Acrosome), enters (Penetration), egg blocks others (Cortical), egg matures (Meiosis II), nuclei fuse (Amphimixis).
questions.hint: Start with the sperm getting ready.

questions.question: Match the cause of Postpartum Hemorrhage with the appropriate management:

richContent.content:
Cause (The 4 Ts)Management
Tone?
Tissue?
Trauma?

questions.explanation: Tone needs contraction (massage/drugs). Tissue needs removal. Trauma needs repair. Thrombin needs factors.
questions.hint: Match the problem to the fix.

questions.question: Identify factors that reduce the accuracy of fundal height measurement: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Obesity, excess fluid, twins, tumors, and a full bladder all distort the measurement of fundal height.
questions.hint: Anything that adds bulk or changes volume.

questions.question: What conditions must be met to diagnose Active Phase Labor? (Select 2)

options.text: Cervical dilatation of at least 4 cm

questions.explanation: Active labor is defined by progressive dilation (typically >4cm) and regular contractions.
questions.hint: Dilation and Contractions.
